body: The whine of chain saws and wood chippers will soon fill the air in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, as hundreds of trees are cut down in the hope of eradicating a beetle that could ruin many woodlands in the Northeast if left unchecked. The trees -- 347 so far on public property and at least 200 more on private land -- are infested with Asian long-horned
title: Brooklyn Trees to Be Felled To Destroy Invading Beetles

body: NEW YORK Children Against Child Labor After reading an article in a children's magazine about Pakistani children toiling 12 hours a day making soccer balls, fourth graders at the Berkeley Carroll School in Brooklyn's Park Slope section began a yearlong project on child labor, joining thousands of others across the nation who have distributed fliers
title: METRO DIGEST

body: Seeking to ease a housing shortage that is growing worse by the month, the Giuliani administration is preparing a broad plan to open up manufacturing areas to residential development while eliminating regulations that it thinks are discouraging housing construction in New York City. Officials said the plan would be the city's most direct response
title: Giuliani Offers Plan to Ease Restrictions on New Housing

body: Adam Baldyga, movie extra for half a day, stood on the stone steps of his Lutheran church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and as the film director went over last-minute instructions and the cameras rolled, saw his own life unfold before his eyes. Not that he has ever been pushed naked out of a speeding, battered van, as one actor was made to do. But as a
title: In Polish Film, Brooklyn Isn't Paved With Zlotys

body: Ten supporters of Ron Carey, the teamsters' president who is running for re-election, were handing out fliers outside a United Parcel Service building in Manhattan on a recent morning when a black van with tinted windows drove up. Suddenly, loudspeakers in the van erupted with a gravelly voice. ''Hoffa, Hoffa, Hoffa,'' came the chant, in support of
title: Bitter Battle for Teamsters' Leadership in New York

body: IT is an imposing building, on Havemeyer Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a former convent made of mellowed brick piled four stories high, complete with turrets and enormous windows. For years, this 100-year-old building was derelict, bought from the Sisters of the Order of St. Dominic in the late 70's by the caretaker of the Church
title: A Former Convent Becomes a Co-op

body: The police arrested an 18-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday in the shooting of a 10-year-old boy in Greenpoint on Halloween. The man, Shaundell Dade, of 330 Frost Street, was charged with first-degree assault and carrying a concealed weapon, the police said. Bail had not yet been set last night. The 10-year-old, Jerzy Rebisz, of 38 Sutton Street, was
title: Arrest in Shooting of Boy

body: Halloween turned into a true-life horror story for a 10-year-old boy in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last night when he was hit by a stray bullet fired during an egg fight that escalated into a gunfight, the police said. The boy, Jerzy Rebisz, of 38 Sutton Street, was listed in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan with a gunshot
title: Boy Hit by Stray Gunfire After Egg Fight

body: AT certain hours, Bedford Avenue seems calm for a thoroughfare. But at other times, as when it is so crowded there are lines for Sunday brunch, you could maybe -- maybe -- mistake it for a Manhattan streetscape. O.K., maybe not. But it is close. There is that lovely Manhattan skyline, stretching across the East River, just a subway stop away. There
title: Trendy Ambiance and Manhattan Views

body: On the edge of Newtown Creek, the city is poised to modernize and expand its largest sewage treatment plant -- a more than $1 billion venture that will bring the 30-year-old facility into compliance with Federal clean water laws. Community leaders, nauseated by the stench from the plant and fed up with having so much of the city's waste dumped in
title: Sewage Plant: No vs. Maybe

body: Dorothy Ellen Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Guy Palmer 2d of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Jordan Straub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Straub of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. David S. Hoag, the rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the church. Msgr. Anthony Dalla Villa, the
title: Robert J. Straub, Dorothy E. Palmer

body: It has been discussed for a decade, undergone several incarnations and been led by three different people. Now, leaders of a committee creating a plan for future development along the waterfront in Williamsburg and Greenpoint say they will release a draft plan later this month. ''It will be a blueprint for redevelopment of the
title: Future Vision: Planners Head in Different Directions

body: Strange, large aliens with long antennae and big appetites have appeared and begun to chew their way through trees in New York City. The invaders are apparently Asian beetles of a sort never before seen in North America. Their targets are maple and horse chestnut trees in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, said experts from the city Parks
title: New York's Newest Invaders: Tree-Eating Beetles From Asia

body: A 10-foot section of parapet wall high up on a garment center office building collapsed under the weight of what authorities called an improperly rigged scaffold yesterday, and a deadly cataract of bricks and coping stones roared down on workers and pedestrians on a busy sidewalk. A workman holding a scaffolding rope on the sidewalk was struck and
title: Worker Is Killed in Collapse Linked to Ill-Rigged Scaffold

body: If furniture could talk, one wonders what a pink leather couch would say of its downward trajectory from centerpiece of a scandal in the Dinkins administration to obscurity in a tidy recreation room of a Greenpoint public housing project. Four years ago, the stylish three-seater, purchased with $3,000 in city funds, became a symbol of former
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT;A Pink Couch, Reincarnated

body: From 1966 until last week, there was a loft in the red-brick building at 285 Lafayette Street where the Bible, the Torah, the Koran and invitations to the White House met: the factory of R. Marchetti and Bro., edge gilders. The six-story building once housed 12 manufacturers in printing or allied trades, but the others left during Manhattan's
title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;A Matter of Survival: Gilders Leave SoHo for Brooklyn

Marchetti and Bro., edge gilders. The six-story building once housed 12 manufacturers in printing or allied trades, but the others left during Manhattan's

body: A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl fell to her death yesterday from the roof of her apartment building after her mother left her in the care of her 12-year-old brother while she went grocery shopping, the police said. The girl, Isabella Zebrowski, was playing with her brother and another friend on the roof of the building, at North Henry Street and Nassau
title: Brooklyn Girl, 7, Falls to Her Death

body: Jillur Rahman has spent five years in his brick house in Midwood, Brooklyn, long enough to know every face on his block and for his 4-year-old son to know no other home. So he was devastated when he received the call from his former landlord telling him that he would have to move and that a judge would decide how soon. What do you say?" Mr. Rahman
title: Bank's Good-Neighbor Efforts Yield Some Unwanted Returns;Risky Mortgages Force Eviction of Paying Tenants

body: PARK SLOPE 9 Seductive Homes Reveal Their Secrets This afternoon, it won't be necessary to peek inside windows to catch a glimpse of nine beautiful Brooklyn homes, each of them more than 100 years old. They will be on the annual Park Slope Civic Council House Tour, this year called "One Hundred Years of Glory," in honor of the council's centennial.
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A police unit equipped with a battering ram and a sledgehammer and carrying a search warrant burst into the Jameel Grocery, a bodega under the rusting tracks of the Z train in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and arrested three clerks one day last week on charges that they sold marijuana to an undercover officer. As they handcuffed the clerks, one, Eric
title: Brooklyn Drug Sweeps Begin to Make Inroads

body: Tim McCann wants more than 15 minutes of fame. The 30-year-old film maker, who lives in Piermont and works as an audio-visual specialist at the Chappaqua Library, made a big splash in three of the most prestigious film festivals of the 1995-96 season, but because of the foibles of show business he hasn't been able to get a distributor for his
title: Film Wins Many Accolades But Few Rewards for Maker

body: To the Editor: I enjoyed your piece on the Lesbian Herstory Archives ("In Lesbian Archive, Education and Sanctuary," April 7). But please note that "pulp novels" should really only refer to periodicals, not paperback books. Paperback books contributed to the demise of the pulps; they weren't the same thing. PATRICK LOZITO Greenpoint, Brooklyn
title: Pulp Means Periodicals, Not Paperback Books

body: Knowing next to no one, Mesut Yaktubay stepped off the plane from Turkey two weeks ago and became an instant regular at Sunny Grocery, a postage-stamp-sized market on an unremarkable corner in Sunnyside, Queens. He does not come for the fava bean paste dip, the fried liver, the shiny pistachio-dappled squares of sobiyet pastry or anything else that
title: In the Queens Mosaic, A Turkish Inlay;Community Takes Root in Sunnyside

body: Artistic acclaim came early to Milo Mottola. When he was 8, his drawing of menacing tooth film with the slogan "Plaque is mean, so keep teeth clean" was such a hit it won him a $50 savings bond from a dental group and was made into a poster. So what if he had to go to a banquet and wear the pink suit his mother picked out? Nearly 25 years later,
title: A Carousel Of Visions;Artist Brings the Fantasies Of Children to Magical Life

body: In the latest move by a large corporation into New York City's troubled garbage hauling industry, Waste Management Inc., the nation's biggest recycling company, said yesterday that it had agreed to a $200 million deal to buy one of the city's largest recycling and trash-collection companies. The acquisition comes amid a broad crackdown by Mayor
title: Major U.S. Recycler to Buy Large New York Trash Company

body: ROBERT KNIGHTLY used to be a cop. Now he's a Legal Aid lawyer. As his "innocent until proven guilty" clients sometimes protest, why would he ever do that? Penance. That's what he tells his buddies from his days pounding a beat in Bushwick and Fort Greene, when they react with shock after learning of his career change. He's half-joking, but says
title: About New York;Trading Badge To Seek Justice Before the Bar

body: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a new solid-waste management plan that will speed up the city's timetable for recycling "mixed paper" and will require residents in all five boroughs to recycle items like cereal boxes, milk cartons and junk mail by the middle of next year. Mixed-paper recycling is now required only on Staten
title: Solid-Waste Management Plan Wins Council Approval

body: MARDI GRAS, or Fat Tuesday, will be celebrated next week. It is a time for indulging in rich foods, especially fried treats, on the day before Ash Wednesday, the beginning of the 40-day Lenten period of abstinence in the Christian calendar. In addition to such well-known pre-Lenten treats as crepes, doughnuts and hot-cross buns, there are also
title: First the Feast, Then the Fast

body: Singleton honors tend to be more valuable in defense than in attack, so a player with such holdings should hesitate to save over an opposing game. When the diagramed deal was played in the Greenpoint Pairs at the Eastern Regional Championships in Manhattan in May, East had to decide whether to save in five hearts when his opponents reached four
title: Bridge

body: An annual visa lottery that strives to diversify immigration to this country has revitalized some New York City neighborhoods, attracting thousands of Irish and Polish immigrants to once-fading neighborhoods, according to city demographers. The annual lottery, which this year will offer coveted green cards to 55,000 foreigners, has been responsible
title: Visa Lottery Is Given Credit For Neighborhood Revival

body: For more than a decade, community groups have fought to get a nursing home built for Greenpoint's growing elderly population. But their efforts to build the home on the site of the old Greenpoint Hospital campus have competed with the city's need to house the homeless, 450 of whom now occupy a shelter on the site. Community residents have marched
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NORTHERN BROOKLYN;Push for Nursing Home Clears Big Hurdle

body: SUNNYSIDE Flamenco Interpretations With Poetic Influence It may take two to tango, but the elaborate footwork and hand movements of flamenco dancing are beautiful to watch whether one, two or five dancers are performing. "Flamenco" will be performed by five dancers from the Andrea Del Conte Danza Espana company, including Ms. Del Conte (left), at
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Most days, Mario Gallegos, a superintendent at an Upper West Side apartment building, leaves the business of tossing bags of refuse onto garbage trucks to New York City sanitation workers. But yesterday, he grabbed a few himself and flung them on the collection truck of Richard L. Bryant and Gene Dalton. Together, the three men loaded about 150
title: Beyond Hills of Snow, Mountains of Garbage

body: Almost a week after a historic blizzard, as mounds of snow are moved and melted, discarded Christmas trees and bags and bags of garbage -- about 50,000 tons of it -- are piling up on sidewalks and in gutters. But the debris will remain until at least Saturday, when limited garbage collection is tentatively scheduled to begin, and it will likely
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: TRASH;Garbage Piled Atop Snow But Pickup May Start Soon

body: Eight slushy, mucky Manhattan blocks after she started out yesterday morning, Winnifred White was close to perfecting her stroller calisthenics. To navigate the Khyber Pass at each snow-heaped corner, Ms. White, a nanny from Mount Vernon, would whirl the stroller backwards, bend herself into a half-crouch, lift up the front wheels and shimmy her
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Now Comes the Challenge Of Snowbanks and Trash

body: While New York City's snowplows worked overtime clearing streets, building managers, store owners and homeowners were rushing to meet Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's deadline to have a path cleared on their sidewalks by 11 A.M. yesterday or face a $50 or $100 fine. By late afternoon, city officials were generally awarding high marks for the
title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: SHOVELING;As Sidewalks Are Cleared, Mountains Meet Lakes
